chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain:
In which of the following examples of motion, can the body be considered approximately a point object:
(a) a railway carriage moving without jerks between two stations.
(b) a monkey sitting on top of a man cycling smoothly on a circular track.
(c) a spinning cricket ball that turns sharply on hitting the ground.
(d) a tumbling beaker that has slipped off the edge of a table.
question_latex:
In which of the following examples of motion, can the body be considered approximately a point object:
(a) a railway carriage moving without jerks between two stations.
(b) a monkey sitting on top of a man cycling smoothly on a circular track.
(c) a spinning cricket ball that turns sharply on hitting the ground.
(d) a tumbling beaker that has slipped off the edge of a table.
hint: A body can be treated as a point object if its size is much smaller than the distance traveled and its orientation/rotation is not relevant to the motion being analyzed.
solution_steps_latex: A body can be considered a point object when its dimensions are negligible compared to the distance covered and when rotational motion is not significant
**Part (a)**: Railway carriage moving between stations - YES
The distance between stations is much larger than the size of the carriage. Since it moves without jerks (smoothly), we can treat it as a point object
**Part (b)**: Monkey on cycling man on circular track - YES
The size of the system is much smaller than the radius of the circular track. For analyzing the motion along the track, we can treat it as a point object
The spinning and turning motion is crucial here. The ball's rotation and orientation matter, so it cannot be treated as a point object
The tumbling motion means rotation is important. We need to consider the beaker's orientation and rotational motion, so it cannot be treated as a point object

to_find: Which can be treated as point objects

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain:
The position-time (x-t) graphs for two children A and B returning from their school O to their homes P and Q respectively are shown in Fig. 2.9. Choose the correct entries in the brackets below;
(a) (A/B) lives closer to the school than (B/A)
(b) (A/B) starts from the school earlier than (B/A)
(c) (A/B) walks faster than (B/A)
(d) A and B reach home at the (same/different) time
(e) (A/B) overtakes (B/A) on the road (once/twice).
question_latex:
The position-time ($x$-$t$) graphs for two children A and B returning from their school O to their homes P and Q respectively are shown in Fig. 2.9. Choose the correct entries in the brackets below;
(a) (A/B) lives closer to the school than (B/A)
(b) (A/B) starts from the school earlier than (B/A)
(c) (A/B) walks faster than (B/A)
(d) A and B reach home at the (same/different) time
(e) (A/B) overtakes (B/A) on the road (once/twice).
correct_answer_plain: (a) A lives closer to school than B, (b) A starts from school earlier than B, (c) B walks faster than A, (d) Same time, (e) B overtakes A once
correct_answer_latex: (a) A lives closer to school than B, (b) A starts from school earlier than B, (c) B walks faster than A, (d) Same time, (e) B overtakes A once
hint: On an x-t graph: distance from school = final position; start time = x-intercept of time axis; speed = slope; overtaking = intersection of graphs.
solution_steps_latex: From Fig. 2.9, we analyze the position-time graphs for children A and B
**Part (a)**: Distance from school = final position on x-axis
Child A reaches position P (lower x-value), Child B reaches position Q (higher x-value)
Therefore, **A lives closer** to the school than B
**Part (b)**: Starting time = when the graph begins (t-intercept)
Child A's graph starts at $t = 0$, Child B's graph starts at a later time
Slope of B's graph is steeper than A's graph
**Part (d)**: Time to reach home = final t-coordinate
Both graphs end at the **same time** on the t-axis
The graphs intersect **once** where B's line crosses A's line

visual_content.diagram_description: Position-time graph showing two straight lines. Line A starts from origin (O) at t=0 with gentle slope reaching point P. Line B starts later with steeper slope, intersects line A, and reaches point Q (farther than P) at the same final time as A.

given: Position-time graphs for children A and B
to_find: Relative distances, start times, speeds, final times, overtaking
formulas_used: Speed = slope of $x$-$t$ graph = $\frac{\Delta x}{\Delta t}$

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain: A woman starts from her home at 9.00 am, walks with a speed of 5 km h⁻¹ on a straight road up to her office 2.5 km away, stays at the office up to 5.00 pm, and returns home by an auto with a speed of 25 km h⁻¹. Choose suitable scales and plot the x-t graph of her motion.
question_latex: A woman starts from her home at 9.00 am, walks with a speed of 5 km h$^{-1}$ on a straight road up to her office 2.5 km away, stays at the office up to 5.00 pm, and returns home by an auto with a speed of 25 km h$^{-1}$. Choose suitable scales and plot the $x$-$t$ graph of her motion.
correct_answer_plain: Graph with three segments: (1) linear from (0,0) to (0.5h, 2.5km), (2) horizontal from (0.5h, 2.5km) to (8.5h, 2.5km), (3) linear from (8.5h, 2.5km) to (8.6h, 0)
correct_answer_latex: Graph with three segments: (1) linear from (0,0) to (0.5h, 2.5km), (2) horizontal from (0.5h, 2.5km) to (8.5h, 2.5km), (3) linear from (8.5h, 2.5km) to (8.6h, 0)
hint: Calculate time for each segment. Walking time = distance/speed. Plot position vs time with three distinct phases.
solution_steps_latex: Let home be at $x = 0$ and time $t = 0$ at 9:00 am
Reaches office at 9:30 am (t = 0.5 h) at position x = 2.5 km
Stays from 9:30 am to 5:00 pm = 7.5 hours
Position remains at x = 2.5 km from t = 0.5 h to t = 8 h
Returns home at 5:06 pm (t = 8.1 h) at position x = 0
Plot with x-axis: time (0 to 9 h), y-axis: position (0 to 3 km)

visual_content.diagram_description: Position-time graph with three segments: (1) upward sloping line representing walk to office, (2) horizontal line representing stay at office, (3) steep downward line representing return journey by auto

to_find: Position-time graph

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain: A drunkard walking in a narrow lane takes 5 steps forward and 3 steps backward, followed again by 5 steps forward and 3 steps backward, and so on. Each step is 1 m long and requires 1 s. Plot the x-t graph of his motion. Determine graphically and otherwise how long the drunkard takes to fall in a pit 13 m away from the start.
question_latex: A drunkard walking in a narrow lane takes 5 steps forward and 3 steps backward, followed again by 5 steps forward and 3 steps backward, and so on. Each step is 1 m long and requires 1 s. Plot the $x$-$t$ graph of his motion. Determine graphically and otherwise how long the drunkard takes to fall in a pit 13 m away from the start.
hint: Net displacement per cycle = 5 - 3 = 2 m in 8 s. Calculate how many complete cycles needed, then add remaining steps.
solution_steps_latex: Given: Each step = 1 m, Each step time = 1 s
Pattern: 5 steps forward, 3 steps backward, repeat
Forward: 5 m in 5 s, Backward: 3 m in 3 s
After 6 cycles: position = 12 m, time = 48 s (too much)

visual_content.diagram_description: Zigzag position-time graph showing repeated pattern: upward slope for 5 seconds, downward slope for 3 seconds, creating a saw-tooth pattern with net upward trend reaching x=13m at t=37s

to_find: Time to reach 13 m
formulas_used: Net displacement = forward steps - backward steps
Total time = number of steps $\times$ 1 s

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain: A car moving along a straight highway with speed of 126 km h⁻¹ is brought to a stop within a distance of 200 m. What is the retardation of the car (assumed uniform), and how long does it take for the car to stop?
question_latex: A car moving along a straight highway with speed of 126 km h$^{-1}$ is brought to a stop within a distance of 200 m. What is the retardation of the car (assumed uniform), and how long does it take for the car to stop?
hint: Convert speed to m/s. Use v² = u² + 2as to find acceleration, then v = u + at to find time.
solution_steps_latex: Given: Initial speed $u = 126$ km h$^{-1}$ = $126 \times \frac{5}{18}$ = 35 m s$^{-1}$

given: Initial speed: 126 km h⁻¹ = 35 m s⁻¹
to_find: Retardation (deceleration)
Time to stop

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain:
A player throws a ball upwards with an initial speed of 29.4 m s⁻¹.
(a) What is the direction of acceleration during the upward motion of the ball?
(b) What are the velocity and acceleration of the ball at the highest point of its motion?
(c) Choose the x = 0 m and t = 0 s to be the location and time of the ball at its highest point, vertically downward direction to be the positive direction of x-axis, and give the signs of position, velocity and acceleration of the ball during its upward, and downward motion.
(d) To what height does the ball rise and after how long does the ball return to the player's hands? (Take g = 9.8 m s⁻² and neglect air resistance).
question_latex:
A player throws a ball upwards with an initial speed of 29.4 m s$^{-1}$.
(a) What is the direction of acceleration during the upward motion of the ball?
(b) What are the velocity and acceleration of the ball at the highest point of its motion?
(c) Choose the $x = 0$ m and $t = 0$ s to be the location and time of the ball at its highest point, vertically downward direction to be the positive direction of $x$-axis, and give the signs of position, velocity and acceleration of the ball during its upward, and downward motion.
(d) To what height does the ball rise and after how long does the ball return to the player's hands? (Take $g = 9.8$ m s$^{-2}$ and neglect air resistance).
correct_answer_plain: (a) Vertically downwards; (b) zero velocity, acceleration of 9.8 m s⁻² downwards; (c) x > 0 (upward and downward motion); v < 0 (upward), v > 0 (downward), a > 0 throughout; (d) 44.1 m, 6 s
correct_answer_latex: (a) Vertically downwards; (b) zero velocity, acceleration of $9.8$ m s$^{-2}$ downwards; (c) $x > 0$ (upward and downward motion); $v < 0$ (upward), $v > 0$ (downward), $a > 0$ throughout; (d) 44.1 m, 6 s
hint: Acceleration due to gravity is always downward. At highest point, velocity = 0 but acceleration = g. Use v² = u² - 2gh for height.
solution_steps_latex: Acceleration due to gravity $g = 9.8$ m s$^{-2}$ (downward)
**Part (a)**: Direction of acceleration during upward motion
Acceleration is always **vertically downwards** (direction of gravity), even during upward motion
**Part (c)**: With origin at highest point, downward as positive:
During **upward motion** (before highest point): $x > 0$, $v < 0$ (moving upward, opposite to positive direction), $a > 0$ (downward, along positive direction)
Using $v^2 = u^2 - 2gh$ (taking upward as positive initially):
Time to reach maximum height using $v = u - gt$:
Total time to return = $2t = 6$ s (by symmetry)

given: Acceleration due to gravity: 9.8 m s⁻²
to_find: (a) Direction of acceleration
(b) Velocity and acceleration at highest point
(c) Signs of position, velocity, acceleration
(d) Maximum height and total time

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain:
Read each statement below carefully and state with reasons and examples, if it is true or false;
A particle in one-dimensional motion
(a) with zero speed at an instant may have non-zero acceleration at that instant
(b) with zero speed may have non-zero velocity,
(c) with constant speed must have zero acceleration,
(d) with positive value of acceleration must be speeding up.
question_latex:
Read each statement below carefully and state with reasons and examples, if it is true or false;
A particle in one-dimensional motion
(a) with zero speed at an instant may have non-zero acceleration at that instant
(b) with zero speed may have non-zero velocity,
(c) with constant speed must have zero acceleration,
(d) with positive value of acceleration must be speeding up.
correct_answer_plain: (a) True; (b) False; (c) True (if the particle rebounds instantly with the same speed, it implies infinite acceleration which is unphysical); (d) False (true only when the chosen positive direction is along the direction of motion)
correct_answer_latex: (a) True; (b) False; (c) True (if the particle rebounds instantly with the same speed, it implies infinite acceleration which is unphysical); (d) False (true only when the chosen positive direction is along the direction of motion)
hint: Think about velocity vs speed, direction matters. Consider examples like ball at highest point, particle changing direction.
solution_steps_latex: **Part (a)**: TRUE - A particle with zero speed at an instant may have non-zero acceleration
**Example**: A ball thrown vertically upward has zero speed at the highest point, but acceleration = $g = 9.8$ m s$^{-2}$ (downward)
**Reason**: Acceleration depends on the rate of change of velocity, not on the instantaneous value of velocity
**Part (b)**: FALSE - A particle with zero speed cannot have non-zero velocity
**Reason**: Speed is the magnitude of velocity. If speed = 0, then $|\vec{v}| = 0$, which means $\vec{v} = 0$
Velocity and speed are zero simultaneously
**Part (c)**: TRUE - A particle with constant speed must have zero acceleration (in one-dimensional motion)
**Reason**: In 1D motion, constant speed means constant velocity (direction doesn't change in 1D)
**Note**: If particle rebounds with same speed, there's a discontinuous change requiring infinite acceleration (unphysical)
**Part (d)**: FALSE - Positive acceleration doesn't necessarily mean speeding up
**Example**: If velocity is negative (moving in negative direction) and acceleration is positive (in positive direction), the particle is actually slowing down
**Reason**: Speeding up occurs when velocity and acceleration have the same sign. If they have opposite signs, particle slows down
The statement is true only when positive direction is chosen along the direction of motion

given: Various scenarios about speed, velocity, and acceleration
to_find: Truth value of each statement with reasoning

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain: A ball is dropped from a height of 90 m on a floor. At each collision with the floor, the ball loses one tenth of its speed. Plot the speed-time graph of its motion between t = 0 to 12 s.
question_latex: A ball is dropped from a height of 90 m on a floor. At each collision with the floor, the ball loses one tenth of its speed. Plot the speed-time graph of its motion between $t = 0$ to 12 s.
correct_answer_plain: Graph showing repeated triangular patterns with decreasing peak speeds: first peak at ~42 m/s, subsequent peaks at 0.9 times previous peak
correct_answer_latex: Graph showing repeated triangular patterns with decreasing peak speeds: first peak at $\approx 42$ m/s, subsequent peaks at 0.9 times previous peak
hint: Calculate initial impact speed using v² = u² + 2gh. After each bounce, speed becomes 0.9 times previous. Time for each journey uses t = v/g.
solution_steps_latex: Height $h = 90$ m, Initial velocity $u = 0$, $g = 10$ m s$^{-2}$ (approx)
Time to fall: $v = u + gt$ → $42 = 0 + 10t$ → $t = 4.2$ s
Ball rises and falls with this speed
Time for up and down = $2 \times \frac{37.8}{10} = 7.56$ s
**Subsequent bounces**: Speed keeps reducing by factor 0.9
Speed increases linearly from 0 to 42 m s$^{-1}$ in first 4.2 s
At each collision, speed drops by 10% (discontinuous drop)
Between collisions, speed increases (falling) then decreases (rising) linearly
Triangular wave pattern with decreasing amplitude

visual_content.diagram_description: Speed-time graph showing saw-tooth pattern. First peak at ~42 m/s at t≈4.2s, then decreasing triangular waves with peaks at 90% of previous height. Each collision shows sudden 10% drop in speed.

given: g = 9.8 m s⁻² (or 10 m s⁻² approx)
to_find: Speed-time graph from t=0 to t=12s

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
correct_answer_plain: (a) Path length ≥ |displacement|, equality when motion is in straight line without reversal; (b) Average speed ≥ |average velocity|, equality when no reversal of direction
correct_answer_latex: (a) Path length $\geq$ |displacement|, equality when motion is in straight line without reversal; (b) Average speed $\geq$ |average velocity|, equality when no reversal of direction
hint: Displacement is straight-line distance between initial and final positions. Path length is actual distance traveled. Think about motion with direction changes.
solution_steps_latex: **Displacement**: Vector from initial to final position. Magnitude $|\Delta \vec{x}| = |x_f - x_i|$
**Example 1**: Particle moves from $x = 0$ to $x = 5$ m directly
**Example 2**: Particle moves from $x = 0$ to $x = 5$ m, then back to $x = 2$ m
Path length is sum of all segments. Displacement is direct distance.
By triangle inequality, path length $\geq$ magnitude of displacement
**Equality**: When particle moves in one direction without reversal
**Equality**: When motion is in one direction without reversal (path length = |displacement|)

visual_content.diagram_description: Two diagrams in the PDF showing: (a) curved path vs straight displacement arrow, (b) circular path showing total path length as circumference vs displacement as diameter

to_find: Distinction between displacement and path length
Distinction between average velocity and average speed
Inequality relationships

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain:
A man walks on a straight road from his home to a market 2.5 km away with a speed of 5 km h⁻¹. Finding the market closed, he instantly turns and walks back home with a speed of 7.5 km h⁻¹. What is the
(a) magnitude of average velocity, and
(b) average speed of the man over the interval of time (i) 0 to 30 min, (ii) 0 to 50 min, (iii) 0 to 40 min?
[Note: You will appreciate from this exercise why it is better to define average speed as total path length divided by time, and not as magnitude of average velocity. You would not like to tell the tired man on his return home that his average speed was zero!]
question_latex:
A man walks on a straight road from his home to a market 2.5 km away with a speed of 5 km h$^{-1}$. Finding the market closed, he instantly turns and walks back home with a speed of 7.5 km h$^{-1}$. What is the
(a) magnitude of average velocity, and
(b) average speed of the man over the interval of time (i) 0 to 30 min, (ii) 0 to 50 min, (iii) 0 to 40 min?
[Note: You will appreciate from this exercise why it is better to define average speed as total path length divided by time, and not as magnitude of average velocity. You would not like to tell the tired man on his return home that his average speed was zero!]
correct_answer_plain: (a) 5 km h⁻¹, 0, 15/8 km h⁻¹; (b) 5 km h⁻¹, 6 km h⁻¹, 45/8 km h⁻¹
hint: First find when he reaches market and returns home. Average velocity = displacement/time. Average speed = total distance/time.
solution_steps_latex: Speed going = 5 km h$^{-1}$, Speed returning = 7.5 km h$^{-1}$
Time to reach market = $\frac{2.5}{5}$ = 0.5 h = 30 min
Time to return home = $\frac{2.5}{7.5}$ = $\frac{1}{3}$ h = 20 min
Total time for round trip = 30 + 20 = 50 min
At $t = 30$ min, man just reaches market. Position = 2.5 km from home
Magnitude of average velocity = $\frac{2.5}{0.5}$ = **5 km h$^{-1}$**
At $t = 50$ min, man returns home. Position = 0 km (back at home)
Magnitude of average velocity = $\frac{0}{50/60}$ = **0 km h$^{-1}$**
Next 10 min: walks back with speed 7.5 km h$^{-1}$
Position at 40 min = $2.5 - 1.25$ = 1.25 km from home
Magnitude of average velocity = $\frac{1.25}{2/3}$ = $1.25 \times \frac{3}{2}$ = $\frac{15}{8}$ = **1.875 km h$^{-1}$**

to_find: Average velocity for three time intervals
Average speed for three time intervals

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain: In Exercises 2.9 and 2.10, we have carefully distinguished between average speed and magnitude of average velocity. No such distinction is necessary when we consider instantaneous speed and magnitude of velocity. The instantaneous speed is always equal to the magnitude of instantaneous velocity. Why?
question_latex: In Exercises 2.9 and 2.10, we have carefully distinguished between average speed and magnitude of average velocity. No such distinction is necessary when we consider instantaneous speed and magnitude of velocity. The instantaneous speed is always equal to the magnitude of instantaneous velocity. Why?
correct_answer_plain: Because, for an arbitrarily small interval of time, the magnitude of displacement is equal to the length of the path.
correct_answer_latex: Because, for an arbitrarily small interval of time, the magnitude of displacement is equal to the length of the path.
hint: Think about what happens as time interval approaches zero. Path length and displacement become identical.
solution_steps_latex: **Average quantities** over finite time interval $\Delta t$:
For finite $\Delta t$, path length $\geq$ |displacement|, so average speed $\geq$ |average velocity|
**Key insight**: As $\Delta t \to 0$, the path becomes infinitesimally small
For an infinitesimally small time interval, the path is essentially a straight line
**Conclusion**: Instantaneous speed = $|\vec{v}|$ = Magnitude of instantaneous velocity
No distinction is needed because at an instant, the particle moves in a definite direction along a straight path

given: Concept of instantaneous vs average quantities
to_find: Why instantaneous speed equals magnitude of instantaneous velocity

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain: Look at the graphs (a) to (d) (Fig. 2.10) carefully and state, with reasons, which of these cannot possibly represent one-dimensional motion of a particle.
question_latex: Look at the graphs (a) to (d) (Fig. 2.10) carefully and state, with reasons, which of these cannot possibly represent one-dimensional motion of a particle.
correct_answer_plain: All the four graphs are impossible. (a) a particle cannot have two different positions at the same time; (b) a particle cannot have velocity in opposite directions at the same time; (c) speed is always non-negative; (d) total path length of a particle can never decrease with time.
correct_answer_latex: All the four graphs are impossible. (a) a particle cannot have two different positions at the same time; (b) a particle cannot have velocity in opposite directions at the same time; (c) speed is always non-negative; (d) total path length of a particle can never decrease with time.
hint: Check: Can a particle be at two positions simultaneously? Can velocity be multi-valued? Can speed be negative? Can path length decrease?
solution_steps_latex: **Graph (a)**: Position vs Time with two branches at same time
**Impossible** - A particle cannot have two different positions at the same instant of time
At a given time $t$, there are two values of $x$, which violates the definition of a function
Physically, a particle can only be at one location at any instant
**Graph (b)**: Velocity vs Time with oscillating/multi-valued function
**Impossible** - A particle cannot have two different velocities at the same time
At a given time $t$, the velocity has multiple values (both positive and negative)
This would mean the particle is moving in opposite directions simultaneously
**Graph (c)**: Speed vs Time showing negative values
Speed is the magnitude of velocity: $\text{speed} = |\vec{v}| \geq 0$
The graph shows negative speed, which is physically meaningless
**Graph (d)**: Total path length vs Time showing decreasing trend
**Impossible** - Total path length can never decrease with time
Path length is cumulative - it can only stay constant (rest) or increase (motion)
A decreasing path length would mean the particle is "unwalking" its previous path
**Note**: The arrows on graphs are meaningless and should be ignored

visual_content.diagram_description: Four graphs labeled (a) to (d): (a) shows x vs t with branching curves, (b) shows v vs t with oscillating multi-valued function, (c) shows Speed vs t dipping into negative values, (d) shows Total path length vs t with decreasing segments

given: Four different graphs of motion variables vs time
to_find: Which graphs are physically impossible and why

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain: Figure 2.11 shows the x-t plot of one-dimensional motion of a particle. Is it correct to say from the graph that the particle moves in a straight line for t < 0 and on a parabolic path for t > 0? If not, suggest a suitable physical context for this graph.
question_latex: Figure 2.11 shows the $x$-$t$ plot of one-dimensional motion of a particle. Is it correct to say from the graph that the particle moves in a straight line for $t < 0$ and on a parabolic path for $t > 0$? If not, suggest a suitable physical context for this graph.
correct_answer_plain: No, wrong. x-t plot does not show the trajectory of a particle. Context: A body is dropped from a tower (x = 0) at t = 0.
correct_answer_latex: No, wrong. $x$-$t$ plot does not show the trajectory of a particle. Context: A body is dropped from a tower ($x = 0$) at $t = 0$.
hint: x-t graph shows how position changes with time, NOT the actual path taken. Think about vertical motion.
solution_steps_latex: **Answer**: No, it is NOT correct to interpret the graph this way
**Important distinction**: An $x$-$t$ graph shows position vs time, NOT the trajectory (actual path) of motion
The shape of the $x$-$t$ graph does not represent the shape of the actual path
**For $t < 0$**: The straight line means position changes uniformly with time
This indicates **uniform velocity** (constant speed in one direction), NOT necessarily straight-line path
**For $t > 0$**: The parabolic curve means position varies as $x \propto t^2$
This indicates **uniformly accelerated motion**, NOT parabolic trajectory
A body is held at position $x = 0$ (say, top of a tower)
For $t < 0$: Body is being raised with constant velocity (straight line with negative slope)
At $t = 0$: Body is released from rest at $x = 0$
For $t > 0$: Body falls freely under gravity
Using $x = \frac{1}{2}gt^2$ (taking downward as positive), we get parabolic $x$-$t$ curve
**The actual motion is along a vertical line** (one-dimensional), not along a parabola

visual_content.diagram_description: Position-time graph showing a straight line for t < 0 passing through origin, then a parabolic curve opening upward for t > 0, both meeting at origin (t=0, x=0)

given: x-t graph with straight line (t<0) and parabola (t>0)
to_find: Correct interpretation of the graph
Physical context

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain: A police van moving on a highway with a speed of 30 km h⁻¹ fires a bullet at a thief's car speeding away in the same direction with a speed of 192 km h⁻¹. If the muzzle speed of the bullet is 150 m s⁻¹, with what speed does the bullet hit the thief's car? (Note: Obtain that speed which is relevant for damaging the thief's car).
question_latex: A police van moving on a highway with a speed of 30 km h$^{-1}$ fires a bullet at a thief's car speeding away in the same direction with a speed of 192 km h$^{-1}$. If the muzzle speed of the bullet is 150 m s$^{-1}$, with what speed does the bullet hit the thief's car? (Note: Obtain that speed which is relevant for damaging the thief's car).
hint: Find relative velocity of bullet with respect to thief's car. Convert all speeds to same units first.
solution_steps_latex: Given: Speed of police van $v_p = 30$ km h$^{-1}$ = $30 \times \frac{5}{18}$ = $\frac{25}{3}$ m s$^{-1}$ $\approx 8.33$ m s$^{-1}$
Speed of thief's car $v_t = 192$ km h$^{-1}$ = $192 \times \frac{5}{18}$ = $\frac{160}{3}$ m s$^{-1}$ $\approx 53.33$ m s$^{-1}$
Muzzle speed of bullet (relative to police van) = 150 m s$^{-1}$
Since bullet is fired from moving van in same direction:
**Speed relevant for damage = Relative speed of bullet w.r.t. thief's car**:
**Answer**: The bullet hits the thief's car with a relative speed of **105 m s$^{-1}$**
This is the speed relevant for damaging the car

given: Police van speed: 30 km h⁻¹ = 8.33 m s⁻¹
Thief's car speed: 192 km h⁻¹ = 53.33 m s⁻¹
to_find: Relative speed of bullet hitting thief's car

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain: Suggest a suitable physical situation for each of the following graphs (Fig 2.12):
question_latex: Suggest a suitable physical situation for each of the following graphs (Fig 2.12):
correct_answer_plain: (a) A ball at rest on a smooth floor is kicked, it rebounds from a wall with reduced speed and moves to the opposite wall which stops it; (b) A ball thrown up with some initial velocity rebounding from the floor with reduced speed after each hit; (c) A uniformly moving cricket ball turned back by hitting it with a bat for a very short time-interval.
correct_answer_latex: (a) A ball at rest on a smooth floor is kicked, it rebounds from a wall with reduced speed and moves to the opposite wall which stops it; (b) A ball thrown up with some initial velocity rebounding from the floor with reduced speed after each hit; (c) A uniformly moving cricket ball turned back by hitting it with a bat for a very short time-interval.
hint: Analyze each graph for position, velocity, and acceleration changes. Look for sudden changes, oscillations, or rebounds.
solution_steps_latex: Shows: Particle at rest (horizontal line at A), sudden position change (vertical drop to B), then remains at new position
A ball resting on a smooth horizontal floor at position A is kicked
It rebounds from a wall with reduced speed (indicated by less steep return)
Finally stops when it hits the opposite wall at position B
Alternative: A book on a table is suddenly pushed to the edge and falls to the floor
Shows: Oscillating velocity with decreasing amplitude, changing sign periodically
Velocity becomes less negative (or less positive) with each cycle
A ball is thrown upward with initial velocity
It bounces on the floor repeatedly, losing speed with each bounce
Velocity alternates between positive (upward) and negative (downward)
Each bounce has reduced peak velocity due to energy loss
Shows: Zero acceleration, sudden spike (impulse), then zero again
A cricket ball moving with uniform velocity (zero acceleration)
Suddenly hit by a bat applying large force for very short time
The impulsive force causes brief high acceleration
After impact, ball moves with new uniform velocity (zero acceleration again)
This represents an **impulsive force** - large force acting for very short duration

visual_content.diagram_description: Three graphs: (a) x vs t showing horizontal line, sudden drop, then horizontal line at lower level; (b) v vs t showing damped oscillation crossing time axis multiple times; (c) a vs t showing zero acceleration with single sharp spike

given: Three different graphs of motion variables vs time
to_find: Physical situations that match each graph

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain: Figure 2.13 gives the x-t plot of a particle executing one-dimensional simple harmonic motion. (You will learn about this motion in more detail in Chapter 13). Give the signs of position, velocity and acceleration variables of the particle at t = 0.3 s, 1.2 s, -1.2 s.
question_latex: Figure 2.13 gives the $x$-$t$ plot of a particle executing one-dimensional simple harmonic motion. (You will learn about this motion in more detail in Chapter 13). Give the signs of position, velocity and acceleration variables of the particle at $t = 0.3$ s, $1.2$ s, $-1.2$ s.
hint: Position sign from graph directly. Velocity sign from slope. In SHM, acceleration is opposite to displacement: a = -ω²x.
solution_steps_latex: From Figure 2.13, we analyze the sinusoidal (cosine-like) $x$-$t$ graph
Velocity $v$: Sign from slope of $x$-$t$ curve (positive slope → positive velocity)
Acceleration in SHM: $a \propto -x$ (always opposite to displacement)
Slope is positive (curve rising from left) → $v > 0$

visual_content.diagram_description: Sinusoidal position-time graph showing simple harmonic motion. The curve oscillates smoothly about x=0, with marked time points at -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3 on t-axis

given: Time instants: t = 0.3 s, 1.2 s, -1.2 s
to_find: Signs of x, v, a at each time instant
formulas_used: In SHM: $a = -\omega^2 x$ (acceleration opposite to displacement)

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain: Figure 2.14 gives the x-t plot of a particle in one-dimensional motion. Three different equal intervals of time are shown. In which interval is the average speed greatest, and in which is it the least? Give the sign of average velocity for each interval.
question_latex: Figure 2.14 gives the $x$-$t$ plot of a particle in one-dimensional motion. Three different equal intervals of time are shown. In which interval is the average speed greatest, and in which is it the least? Give the sign of average velocity for each interval.
correct_answer_plain: Greatest in 3, least in 2; v > 0 in 1 and 2, v < 0 in 3
correct_answer_latex: Greatest in 3, least in 2; $v > 0$ in 1 and 2, $v < 0$ in 3
hint: Average speed = |displacement|/time. Average velocity = displacement/time (with sign). Look at change in position.
solution_steps_latex: From Figure 2.14, we have three equal time intervals labeled 1, 2, and 3
Displacement is positive and moderate (moving upward on graph)
Displacement is very small (nearly horizontal portion of curve)
The curve is nearly flat → smallest change in position
Average velocity: **positive** but very small (slight increase in x)
Displacement is negative and large in magnitude (steep downward slope)
Signs: $v > 0$ in intervals 1 and 2, $v < 0$ in interval 3

visual_content.diagram_description: Position-time graph showing a curve that rises gradually (interval 1), plateaus (interval 2), then drops steeply (interval 3). Three equal time intervals are marked on the t-axis.

given: x-t graph with three equal time intervals
to_find: Interval with greatest average speed
Interval with least average speed
Sign of average velocity in each interval

chapter: Class XI - Chapter 2: Motion in a Straight Line
question_plain: Figure 2.15 gives a speed-time graph of a particle in motion along a constant direction. Three equal intervals of time are shown. In which interval is the average acceleration greatest in magnitude? In which interval is the average speed greatest? Choosing the positive direction as the constant direction of motion, give the signs of v and a in the three intervals. What are the accelerations at the points A, B, C and D?
question_latex: Figure 2.15 gives a speed-time graph of a particle in motion along a constant direction. Three equal intervals of time are shown. In which interval is the average acceleration greatest in magnitude? In which interval is the average speed greatest? Choosing the positive direction as the constant direction of motion, give the signs of $v$ and $a$ in the three intervals. What are the accelerations at the points A, B, C and D?
correct_answer_plain: Acceleration magnitude greatest in 2; speed greatest in 3; v > 0 in 1, 2 and 3; a > 0 in 1 and 3, a < 0 in 2; a = 0 at A, B, C, D
correct_answer_latex: Acceleration magnitude greatest in 2; speed greatest in 3; $v > 0$ in 1, 2 and 3; $a > 0$ in 1 and 3, $a < 0$ in 2; $a = 0$ at A, B, C, D
hint: Acceleration = slope of v-t graph. At peak/valley points (A,B,C,D), slope = 0. Speed read from graph directly.
solution_steps_latex: From Figure 2.15, analyzing the speed-time graph with three equal intervals
Speed is always positive (moving in constant direction)
Positive slope → positive acceleration; Negative slope → negative acceleration
**Interval 1**: Speed increases from A to B
Slope is positive but moderate → $a > 0$, moderate magnitude
**Interval 2**: Speed decreases from B to C (steep negative slope)
**Interval 3**: Speed increases from C to D
Average speed = average height on the graph
Motion is in positive direction throughout, so $v > 0$ always
**Accelerations at points A, B, C, D**:
These are turning points (maxima/minima) where slope = 0
At B: $a = 0$ (local maximum, slope changes from + to -)
At C: $a = 0$ (local minimum, slope changes from - to +)

visual_content.diagram_description: Speed-time graph showing wave-like pattern with points A, B, C, D marked. Three equal time intervals labeled 1, 2, 3. Graph shows speed increasing to B, decreasing to C, then increasing to D.

given: Marked points A, B, C, D
to_find: Interval with greatest acceleration magnitude
Interval with greatest average speed
Signs of v and a in each interval
Acceleration at points A, B, C, D
